newsitem.title: USA: CBOT wheat closes lower on Australian crop outlook. [CORRECTED 23:56 GMT]
newsitem.headline: CBOT wheat closes lower on Australian crop outlook. [CORRECTED 23:56 GMT]

text.p: CBOT wheat futures closed lower on a crop estimate released by the Australian Wheat Board (AWB), traders said.
"The Australian Wheat Board (AWB) estimate hit the wheat and commercials sold it," said Vic Lespinasse of Dean Witter Reynolds.
The AWB early Monday pegged the 1996-97 AWB wheat crop at 23.0 (corrects from 22.0) million tonnes, above the previous estimate for 21.5 million tonnes.
Also diminished concerns about winterkill in the U.S. winter wheat areas weighed on the market, they said.
"Everything was bearish this morning. There was no bullish news to trade on," said Skip Searcy, wheat specialist for FIMAT Futures.
Friday's Commodity Futures Trading Commission Commitments of Traders report provided little direction. The CFTC said as of January 14 funds were long wheat 41 million bushels and short 51 million.
Wheat closed two to six cents per bushel lower, with March down three at $3.77-1/2 a bushel.
Wheat futures volume was estimated at 21,000 contracts, above the 15,249 traded Friday, according to the CBOT.
In wheat options, Paine Webber sold 500 March $3.90 puts at 16-1/2 to 17 cents, FIMAT Futures bought 400 May $3.70 puts and sold 400 May $3.60 puts at 5-3/4 cents, traders said.
Wheat options volume was estimated at 6,000 contracts, above the 2,884 traded Friday.
